G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, and the common law covenant of quiet enjoyment, seeking damages and other relief arising out of Defendant’s breach of Plaintiff’s right to the quiet enjoyment of her tenancy.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: The Boston Housing Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action involving residential housing located in Boston, Massachusetts and concerns the relationship of landlord and tenant and the use and condition of residential premises.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because the Premises are located within the territorial jurisdiction of the Boston Housing Court and the acts and omissions complained of occurred there.

Massachusetts General Laws (\u201cG.L.\u.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts General Laws (“G.L.”) c. 186 and applicable Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Landlords have an obligation to maintain residential premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and applicable housing regulations, and violations of those standards that substantially impair the health or safety of tenants or materially interfere with their use and enjoyment of the premises may constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Landlords have an obligation to maintain residential premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and applicable housing regulations, and violations of those standards that substantially impair the health or safety of tenants or materially interfere with their use and enjoyment of the premises may constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.

105 C.M.R. 410.500 et seq..proposition: Under 105 C.M.R. 410.500 et seq., the State Sanitary Code requires that the roof, walls, windows, and structural elements of residential dwellings be watertight, weather-tight, and free from chronic dampness, leaks, and conditions conducive to mold and mildew.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre- and post-judgment interest as allowed by law pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibits serious and substantial interference with the tenant’s tenancy, including interference with the tenant’s right to use and enjoy the leased premises for residential purposes.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that a landlord breaches the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment when its conduct or permitted conditions ‘very substantially’ deprive tenants of quiet enjoyment, and it applies that rule to serious noise and disturbances that rendered the residential premises not reasonably habitable. The opinion frames the harm as interference with the tenants’ use and enjoyment of their apartments for residential purposes and treats such substantial interference as a constructive eviction and violation of quiet enjoyment. This squarely aligns with the proposition about serious and substantial interference with residential use.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’… He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibits serious and substantial interference with the tenant’s tenancy, including interference with the tenant’s right to use and enjoy the leased premises for residential purposes.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the meaning of “quiet enjoyment” in Massachusetts landlord–tenant law and explains that it protects the tenant from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises, citing and adopting that common‑law understanding in construing G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court emphasizes that the statutory ‘quiet enjoyment’ language incorporates this background and that interference with sanitary conditions and repeated flooding that impairs use of the dwelling falls within that protection, thereby supporting the proposition that the covenant covers serious and substantial interferences with residential use and enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibits serious and substantial interference with the tenant’s tenancy, including interference with the tenant’s right to use and enjoy the leased premises for residential purposes.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the fault requirement (at least negligence and notice) necessary to establish a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, especially in the context of lead paint violations. It does not discuss or define the covenant in terms of “serious and substantial interference” or specifically frame it as protecting the tenant’s right to use and enjoy premises for residential purposes; those formulations come from other cases like Simon or Cruz, which are cited but not restated here. Thus, this case does not itself establish the interference-based standard described in the proposition.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. In 1973, the statute was rewritten and the requirement of intentional conduct was eliminated; landlords could now be held liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy recurring water leaks, structural problems, or conditions affecting health and safety can constitute an unlawful “interference” under G.L. c. 186, § 14, even if the landlord’s conduct is characterized as an omission rather than an affirmative act.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 to cover a landlord’s omissions that permit conditions seriously interfering with tenants’ use and enjoyment. The court emphasizes that liability turns on the natural and probable consequences of “what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done,” and holds that a failure to take measures to remedy or remove serious interfering conditions on property the landlord controls can breach the covenant. Although the facts involve criminal activity rather than leaks or structural defects, the legal principle squarely encompasses omissions affecting health and safety as potential ‘interference’ under § 14.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … [A] landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … [I]f the defendant has failed to take any measures…then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mass. 1.proposition: Landlords have an obligation to maintain residential premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and applicable housing regulations, and violations of those standards that substantially impair the health or safety of tenants or materially interfere with their use and enjoyment of the premises may constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: This separate opinion explicitly states that housing statutes, regulations, and the State Sanitary Code impose on landlords, for the benefit of tenants, an obligation to comply with minimum standards, and that these obligations should be mutually interdependent with rent. It also endorses the idea that material failure to comply with such standards affects the tenant’s right to rent and use of the premises, which tracks the concept underlying breaches of quiet enjoyment, even though the opinion is framed in terms of implied agreements/warranties rather than G.L. c. 186, § 14 specifically. Because this is a concurrence/dissent rather than the majority, and it does not squarely use the “quiet enjoyment” label, the support is indirect rather than explicit.
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Landlords have an obligation to maintain residential premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and applicable housing regulations, and violations of those standards that substantially impair the health or safety of tenants or materially interfere with their use and enjoyment of the premises may constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly ties the landlord’s contractual and warranty obligations to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and recognizes that substantial Sanitary Code violations render a dwelling uninhabitable. It further notes that the landlord must at least meet minimum building and sanitary code standards as part of the warranty of habitability, and that such violations give rise to tenant remedies (including rent abatement) when they materially affect habitability, which encompasses the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises. While the case’s primary remedy is rent abatement rather than a § 14 quiet enjoyment claim, its reasoning directly supports the proposition that serious sanitary code violations breaching habitability obligations can constitute a legally cognizable interference with tenants’ rights.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “‘[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition….’ Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, supra at 198…. A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. … [T]he landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question. Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451 (1979).”

*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 244\u.proposition: A landlord may be found to have breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment where, after notice of serious defects, the landlord fails to take reasonable steps to repair them within a reasonable time.
*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 244\u.support_reasoning: The opinion in Lipsitt v. Plaud concerns whether the Massachusetts Wage Act is the exclusive remedy for unpaid wages and whether common-law contract and quasi-contract claims are preempted, along with issues of piercing the corporate veil. It does not address landlord-tenant law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, or a landlord’s duty to repair defects after notice. Therefore it cannot be authority for the stated proposition about breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 244\u.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we are asked to decide whether G. L. c. 149, §§ 148 and 150 (Wage Act), are intended to be the exclusive remedy for the recovery of unpaid wages under Massachusetts law, preempting common-law breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims. We conclude that they are not.”
